node.title: Biden social spending package discussions to continue with Auto CEOs
node.description: The CEOs of top U.S. automakers and other industry heads are expected to meet at the White House on Wednesday to talk about reviving parts of the spending bill.
node.content: ["The CEOs of top American automakers and other heads of industry are expected to meet at the White House on Wednesday to discuss the future of President Biden's proposed social and climate spending package, a person familiar with the meeting plans told CBS News. \u00a0", "General Motors CEO Mary Barra and Ford CEO Jim Farley are expected to attend the meeting, the source added. These two leaders of two of the three big auto manufacturers in the U.S. are expected to advocate for tax credits for electric vehicles and the infrastructure to support them. The original Build Back Better proposal included around $12,500 in tax credits for buyers of new and used electrical vehicle purchases.\u00a0", "GM on Tuesday announced a $7 billion dollar investment into four facilities for electric vehicle production in Michigan. Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer, a close ally of Mr. Biden's, said her state will be \"leading the way in electrifying.\"\u00a0", "Last week, Mr. Biden admitted his proposed $1.7 trillion dollar spending package \u2014 named for his campaign slogan \"Build Back Better\" \u2014 wasn't likely to pass in its current form and would likely have to be broken into \"chunks.\" \u00a0", "\"It's clear to me that we are going to have to probably break it up,\" Mr. Biden said at his first news conference of the year, explaining his hope that certain environmental provisions to address climate change could be passed. \u00a0", "The head of climate change policy at the White House, Gina McCarthy, expressed confidence last week that tax credits for electric vehicles could remain in the narrower social spending package. \"I'm not seeing any dispute about the need to continue to make sure that these technologies are affordable and accessible to everyone,\" McCarthy said at the Washington Auto Show, according to\u00a0Bloomberg. \u00a0", "Mr. Biden also admitted last week that two popular but more costly provisions \u2014 free community college and an extension of the child tax credit \u2014 would likely have to be cut from the spending package for other elements to pass. \u00a0", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
